ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: This course required asynchronous learning days as well that required connection to various materials on days outside of live virtual lectures.
Synchronous lecture three days a week, with asynchronous learning the other two days. Occasionally, we would have a test or quiz on one of the asynchronous days.
Asynchronous work was assigned on Tuesdays and Thursdays in place of class meetings.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course helped me understand basic Spanish verbs and helped me gain knowledge of the cultures of the Spanish-speaking world.

This course gave me a strong understanding of basic Spanish grammar and vocabulary, but it also provided me with knowledge about various Spanish-speaking countries around the world. This class placed so much emphasis on culture and conversation, and I felt that this really helped me to improve my Spanish.

I continued to practice and advance my Spanish speaking abilities. In addition, Juliana spent significant time on the varying cultures between different Spanish speaking countries putting particular emphasis on those less commonly talked abut in the U.S. She encouraged students do do their on research on topics which encouraged Spanish literacy and then present on those topics which developed presentational speaking skills.
I developed the ability to write, read, and speak Spanish at a proficient level.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was really well designed and I have no feedback for how it could be improved.

No weaknesses. The strength of this course lies in the high level of engagement, the energy levels of the professor, and the small class size. I think the source was well-formatted, especially in COVID times.

Strengths: Juliana was very invested in the material, immersion encourages speaking and progress

Weakness: Most weeks one of the asynchronous days were taken by some form of assessment which increased burnout.

This course does a great job of actively having you practice your Spanish reading, writing, and speaking ability. The assignments are given out consistently and often throughout the semester, but they are generally not too difficult. Using only Spanish in class was also really useful as it helped develop my ability to speak more coherently. Professor Ramos-Ruano is also great and brings a lot of enthusiasm to the class, making the material more engaging.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: My professor always made herself available, which really made distance learning all that much easier.

I liked the combination of synchronous and asynchronous learning. This was one of the classes I felt most engaged in this semester, because there weren't any recorded lectures. The size of my section (5 students) was especially beneficial. Zoom is not exactly conducive to an interactive class, but the small class size "forced" participation, so that really wasn't a problem.

I think making assignments due a the beginning of each sections meeting time is an adjustment that should be made so that way there is a consistent deadline. The powerpoint presentations providing visuals for classes helped to keep everyone on the same page.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course.  Professor Ramos-Ruano was incredible and this course is well designed to learn the Spanish language.

I would recommend this class to other students who have had previous exposure to reading, writing, and speaking Spanish from another Yale or high school course. It truly allows you to develop your grammatical and speaking skills a lot. The material covered is also interesting and presented in an engaging format through useful activities and assignments.
